title: Stanley Kubrick, typophile
content:
Interesting [article](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518052348/http:/film.guardian.co.uk/features/featurepages/0%2C4120%2C1177734%2C00.html) in today’s Guardian about Kubrick�s archive.

> * * *
> **quote:**
> 
> �It's Futura Extra Bold,� explains Tony. �It was Stanley's favourite typeface. It's sans serif. He liked Helvetica and Univers, too. Clean and elegant.�   
>    
> �Is this the kind of thing you and Kubrick used to discuss?� I ask.   
>    
> �God, yes,� says Tony. �Sometimes late into the night. I was always trying to persuade him to turn away from them. But he was wedded to his sans serifs.�   
>    
> Tony goes to his bookshelf and brings down a number of volumes full of examples of typefaces, the kind of volumes he and Kubrick used to study, and he shows them to me. �I did once get him to admit the beauty of Bembo,� he adds, �a serif.�
> 
> * * *
author: puffinry

comments.content: Thanks for the link Robin: that is a fascinating article. The author, Jon Ronson, also wrote one of the most interesting, disturbing yet hilarious books I read last year: [_Them._](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518052348/http:/www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/0330375466/qid=1080414383/sr=1-1/ref=sr_1_1/104-9071209-7311916?v=glance&s=books)

It's easy but surprising to overlook the extent to which Kubrick has contributed to my own visual aesthetic. I've recommended display-sized Futura to two separate clients in the last 6 months, and pounded one marketing manager with a femur.

John Hudson: I have seen this book, and it really caught my eye, is it worth the read?   
IS it REALLY disturbing (because I cant handle such). A cool concept though.
_Them_ is more funny than disturbing, and probably also more sad. I really recommend it.
